entry.title: nodejs web server docker
entry.content:
Create a node.js web server running on docker.

create an index.js.

// index.js
const express = require('express');
const app = express();
const port = 3000;

app.get('/', (req, res) => {
  res.send('Hello from Node.js in Docker!');
});

app.listen(port, () => {
  console.log(`App listening at http://localhost:${port}`);
});

install node

sudo apt install npm
npm init -y
npm install express

create a Dockerfile

# Dockerfile
FROM node:alpine
WORKDIR /app
COPY package*.json ./
RUN npm install
COPY . .
EXPOSE 3000
CMD ["node", "index.js"]

create docker-compose.yml file

# docker-compose.yml
version: '3.8'
services:
  web:
    build: .
    ports:
      - "3000:3000"
    volumes:
      - .:/app
    environment:
      NODE_ENV: development # Or production

finally, start the node.js web application in a docker container

docker-compose up -d
entry.summary: Create a node.js web server running on docker.

entry.title: viltrox 28mm f4.5 af
entry.content:
I purchased a pancake lens from Viltrox. It’a 28m lens which is a 42mm equivalent on full frame. It comes with a fixed aperture at f4.5 with autofocus. It’s sharp in the center as well as in the edges. There’s a little bit of vignetting on the edges and some flare if you shoot at certain angles at the sun. It’s not quite up to par with the other Viltrox 27mm f1.2 that I own, but it’s super lightweight lens and easy to carry around. It’s perfect lens for street photography if you just want to snap pictures randomly without lugging a heavy lens.

It does struggle a little bit with focusing. You may have to hold your camera steady for a few seconds to nail down the focus. Otherwise, it’s a fun little lens for just $99. I got mine at a discount at $79 that’s why I jumped at the chance. Since the lens is a fixed aperture at f4.5, it will struggle some at night. It’s not totally impossible. You just have to be steady. I’m so used to f1.2 that I forget sometimes other lenses are much slower.

So, give it a try if you are looking for portability. If you’re looking something more with a better quality lens and better focusing and less flare, try the other Viltrox lens that I own, which is the Viltrox 27mm f1.2. Just be mindful of the size and weight. I don’t mind at all. I took it to Europe for 2 weeks and I didn’t find it cumbersome.

entry.title: list file types
entry.content:
How to list file types in the current directory.

#!/bin/bash
fileTypes=("/*.NEF" "/*.JPG")
for i in "${fileTypes[@]}" ; do
  echo $i
done

entry.title: viltrox 27mm f1.2
entry.content:
Just started shooting on a Viltrox 27mm f1.2.

Here are pros and cons.

Pros:

  • sharp all around from 1.2 all the way to f11 before defraction takes over
  • no barrel or pin cushion distortion
  • no chromatic abberation

Cons:

  • heavy lens especially if fitted on a smaller camera
  • vignetting at f1.2. it goes away at around f4.
  • little bit of flare when shot directly at a light

Otherwise, fantastic lens with super sharp results.
entry.summary: Just started shooting on a Viltrox 27mm f1.2.
